content:
ass="word-wrap-span">This piece is from 1843 , our sister magazine of ideas, lifestyle and culture. It was published in the ass="word-wrap-span">June/July 2019 issue.

I ass="word-wrap-span">SHOW UP at ass="word-wrap-span">Samantha ass="word-wrap-span">Power’s hass="word-wrap-span">Andsome clapboard house outside ass="word-wrap-span">Concord, Massachusetts, a little after 8.30am, bleary-eyed ass="word-wrap-span">And ratass="word-wrap-span">Her nervous. I have not merely arranged to interview Barack Obama’s former human-rights guru ass="word-wrap-span">And ass="word-wrap-span">ambassador to ass="word-wrap-span">The UN. ass="word-wrap-span">She has also suggested we run togetass="word-wrap-span">Her. ass="word-wrap-span">And having been up half ass="word-wrap-span">The night reading ass="word-wrap-span">Power’s doorstopper of a new memoir, a late arrival from its publisass="word-wrap-span">Her, I am slightly dreading whatever workout ass="word-wrap-span">She might have in mind. ass="word-wrap-span">Almost as an aside in ass="word-wrap-span">Her book, “ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Education of an ass="word-wrap-span">idealist”, ass="word-wrap-span">She describes running ass="word-wrap-span">The Boston marathon in ass="word-wrap-span">Her early 20s (for ass="word-wrap-span">The first of several times). ass="word-wrap-span">Her running mates wrote witty slogans on ass="word-wrap-span">Their T-shirts to draw shouts from ass="word-wrap-span">The crowd. ass="word-wrap-span">Fresh from a stint of war reporting in Bosnia, ass="word-wrap-span">She wrote on ass="word-wrap-span">Hers: “ass="word-wrap-span">Remember Srebrenica – 8,000 ass="word-wrap-span">Bosnian ass="word-wrap-span">Muslim men ass="word-wrap-span">And boys murdered”. ass="word-wrap-span">Power is not to be taken lightly.

ass="word-wrap-span">Tall, athletic and still flame-haired at 48, ass="word-wrap-span">The former diplomat answers ass="word-wrap-span">The door in running gear – purple shorts and a grey T-shirt – and fixes me in ass="word-wrap-span">The eye. “ass="word-wrap-span">Have we met before?” she asks. ass="word-wrap-span">Then, noting that I’m not dressed to run, she wants to know why.

ass="word-wrap-span">Maybe we should start over coffee? I say sheepishly. “Oh, ass="word-wrap-span">absolutely!” she perks up, in an ass="word-wrap-span">accent tinged with a ass="word-wrap-span">Dublin brogue from her Irish upbringing. “I mean, we don’t have to run at all if you don’t want to?” ass="word-wrap-span">Power, it turns out, loathes running. “It’s painful, it’s boring,” she grumbles. ass="word-wrap-span">But hang on, what about all those marathons? “Oh, they were just to motivate me to run five miles a day,” she says, dismissively. “If I didn’t, I would feel horrible. ass="word-wrap-span">And, of course, as a woman it was important to me to try to look good.”

ass="word-wrap-span">The streets of Washington, DC, are crowded with obsessively self-improving runners – hyper-ambitious policy wonks and ass="word-wrap-span">Congressional staffers, such as ass="word-wrap-span">Power once was, padding along ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Potomac and ass="word-wrap-span">National ass="word-wrap-span">Mall. ass="word-wrap-span">She went into government via a brief stretch as a journalist: ass="word-wrap-span">Her first book, a history of ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America’s passive response to atrocities in ass="word-wrap-span">Rwanda and elsewass="word-wrap-span">Here, brought ass="word-wrap-span">Her to ass="word-wrap-span">The attention of Obama, ass="word-wrap-span">Then state senator, for whom ass="word-wrap-span">She later worked in ass="word-wrap-span">Congress, ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">White ass="word-wrap-span">House and at ass="word-wrap-span">The UN in ass="word-wrap-span">New York. ass="word-wrap-span">She ran tass="word-wrap-span">Here, too. ass="word-wrap-span">Her ass="word-wrap-span">ambassadorial security guards used to jostle to avoid running with ass="word-wrap-span">Her through ass="word-wrap-span">Central ass="word-wrap-span">Park and ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">New York countryside. “I am not fast, but I have a certain stamina,” ass="word-wrap-span">She says modestly. I recall ass="word-wrap-span">The verdict of one of ass="word-wrap-span">Her (admiring) former aides at ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">White ass="word-wrap-span">House: “ass="word-wrap-span">She’s relentless – not everyone could keep up with ass="word-wrap-span">Her demands.”

ass="word-wrap-span">Power was perhaps the staunchest proponent of liberal internationalism in Obama’s cabinet. ass="word-wrap-span">That made ass="word-wrap-span">Her a target for his critics. ass="word-wrap-span">Her openness to military intervention – ass="word-wrap-span">She was against it in Iraq but for it in ass="word-wrap-span">Libya – drew flak from the left. As UN ass="word-wrap-span">ambassador, ass="word-wrap-span">She was eviscerated by right-wingers for writing emails criticising the incoming ass="word-wrap-span">Trump team. ass="word-wrap-span">She has continued to question its policies from ass="word-wrap-span">Her new perch as a Harvard ass="word-wrap-span">Law ass="word-wrap-span">School professor, especially the administration’s relative disregard for human rights, for which ass="word-wrap-span">She remains a forceful ass="word-wrap-span">advocate.

ass="word-wrap-span">Her book is part of that effort. It was envisaged as a record of Obama’s administration, ass="word-wrap-span">But became ass="word-wrap-span">Her life story. ass="word-wrap-span">She hopes it will help restore the public’s flagging faith in the integrity of government and its ability to do good. ass="word-wrap-span">She argues that Obama’s foreign policy was less cautious and more humanitarian than is often thought. ass="word-wrap-span">She makes a decent case, even if ass="word-wrap-span">Her own relentless high-mindedness risks coming over as preachy at times. ass="word-wrap-span">Reading ass="word-wrap-span">Her book I stumbled over lines such as: “I felt a profound disconnect between my personal good fortune and the state of the world.” ass="word-wrap-span">Power’s brief spell as a journalist is an important part of ass="word-wrap-span">Her self-image; ass="word-wrap-span">She sees ass="word-wrap-span">Herself as a truth-seeker, not a bureaucrat. ass="word-wrap-span">But few calloused foreign correspondents would write so ingenuously. ass="word-wrap-span">Quite who does ass="word-wrap-span">She think ass="word-wrap-span">She is?

ass="word-wrap-span">She gave some sense of the answer on our drive into ass="word-wrap-span">Concord with her ten-year-old son Declan, whom we planned to drop off at baseball camp before our jog. I had rashly expressed cautious surprise at the significance ass="word-wrap-span">She attaches in her book to Declan being born on ass="word-wrap-span">Armenian ass="word-wrap-span">Genocide ass="word-wrap-span">Remembrance ass="word-wrap-span">Day. “ass="word-wrap-span">But why?” ass="word-wrap-span">She asked sharply. ass="word-wrap-span">She had lobbied the Obama administration, unsuccessfully, to recognise the 1915 massacre of ass="word-wrap-span">Armenians as the ass="word-wrap-span">Genocide that it was. “ass="word-wrap-span">And every year we light cass="word-wrap-span">Andles to remember the ass="word-wrap-span">Armenian ass="word-wrap-span">Genocide. It’s important to us as a family.” I now felt chastened. ass="word-wrap-span">What I had found slightly self-aggrass="word-wrap-span">Andising, ass="word-wrap-span">Power appeared to see as an almost sacred opportunity for ass="word-wrap-span">Remembrance.

ass="word-wrap-span">What sustains such idealism? ass="word-wrap-span">Her immigrant spirit – a sense of ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America as a place of redemptive potential – must be part of the answer. ass="word-wrap-span">Her motass="word-wrap-span">Her brought ass="word-wrap-span">Her to ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America aged nine, to escape ass="word-wrap-span">Power’s beloved but irretrievably ass="word-wrap-span">alcoholic fatass="word-wrap-span">Her. ass="word-wrap-span">Her book contains a poignant description of ass="word-wrap-span">Her blighted childhood, dominated by his slow descent into ass="word-wrap-span">addiction and ill health, and of ass="word-wrap-span">Her new life in ass="word-wrap-span">Pittsburgh. Having kept in close contact with Ireland – she is still an Irish citizen and visits ass="word-wrap-span">Her family tass="word-wrap-span">Here every year – ass="word-wrap-span">Her memory of that contrast remains keen, perhaps uncomfortably so. ass="word-wrap-span">When I tell ass="word-wrap-span">Her I was moved by ass="word-wrap-span">Her description of ass="word-wrap-span">Her fatass="word-wrap-span">Her’s death, at 47, as he lay alone in ass="word-wrap-span">Her childhood bed, she winces: “ass="word-wrap-span">Let’s see how it goes down in Ireland. ass="word-wrap-span">You know how it is in families. ass="word-wrap-span">Most of those events have not been discussed in 30 years.”

ass="word-wrap-span">Pepped up by caffeine, I am now eager to get running. ass="word-wrap-span">But ass="word-wrap-span">Power looks unenthusiastic: “It’s probably like 1,000 degrees out there.” I check the temperature on my phone, which indicates a pleasant 26 degrees. “ass="word-wrap-span">Fine then, ass="word-wrap-span">But I’m not sure ass="word-wrap-span">How far you want to run,” she says. “ass="word-wrap-span">How about three or four miles?” I suggest. ass="word-wrap-span">With a look of relief, she confesses she had been dreading something much longer.

We set off at a gentle trot towards ass="word-wrap-span">Concord’s famous battlefield. Its lovely water meadows echoed in 1775 with the “shot heard around the world”, in Ralph ass="word-wrap-span">Waldo ass="word-wrap-span">Emerson’s phrase, at the start of the revolutionary war. ass="word-wrap-span">For sure, the inhabitants of nearby ass="word-wrap-span">Lexington also claim to have hosted the first shot, which ass="word-wrap-span">Power ass="word-wrap-span">acknowledges as we weave through a stream of tourists headed toward the river where the fighting took place. ass="word-wrap-span">But ass="word-wrap-span">Concord was where the ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Americans first fired back at their British ass="word-wrap-span">aggressors, she says firmly, as we cross the river and head towards the surrounding woods. ass="word-wrap-span">Indeed, the house she shares with her two children and husband Cass Sunstein, a fellow Obama ass="word-wrap-span">alumnus and Harvard professor, was part of that drama: it was used as a weapons store by the militiamen ahead of the battle. It seems ass="word-wrap-span">appropriate that, having conquered ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America’s establishment, ass="word-wrap-span">Power should own a piece of its most treasured history.

We re-emerge from the woods and circle back to the battlefield, completing a two-mile loop. It is gone noon but still pleasant. I suggest another circuit, but ass="word-wrap-span">Power, checking her watch, is reluctant to go on. ass="word-wrap-span">She has a lot to do – and ass="word-wrap-span">She much prefers ball-games to running, ass="word-wrap-span">She says wistfully. “ass="word-wrap-span">Basketball, squash, anything with a wall.”

ass="word-wrap-span">During her stint at ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">White ass="word-wrap-span">House she shot hoops with its security guards. ass="word-wrap-span">Only once did she receive a coveted invitation to join ass="word-wrap-span">The president on court – and, to ass="word-wrap-span">The astonishment of her colleagues, she turned him down. ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Haiti earthquake had just happened. “It became this thing…me and ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Haiti earthquake,” she tails off, sounding mildly embarrassed, or perhaps still halfway unsure what all ass="word-wrap-span">The fuss was about. ass="word-wrap-span">Not many ass="word-wrap-span">White ass="word-wrap-span">House officials would turn down an opportunity to go one-on-one with ass="word-wrap-span">The president; ass="word-wrap-span">Not many are so conscientious.

I had expected to run with her for as long as we talked together; it hasn’t turned out that way. ass="word-wrap-span">Power is a better – and certainly more enthusiastic – talker than she is a runner. ass="word-wrap-span">Even so, our jog through the battlefield had established enough sweaty rapport to leave us mildly confused about our footing. As we said goodbye outside her house, I stuck out my hand just as ass="word-wrap-span">Power opened her arms for a friendly hug. I was as touched by her pleasantness as I was impressed by her cleverness. ass="word-wrap-span">Speaking up for government isn’t easy; with her pavement-pounding stamina she does it well.

ass="word-wrap-span">James Astill is ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Economist ’s Washington bureau chief and ass="word-wrap-span">Lexington columnist
